text: , also known as Semmei-reki or Xuanming li, was a Japanese lunisolar calendar (genka reki).Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Calendar" in Japan Encyclopedia, pp. 98-99. It was used from the late-9th century to the late-17th century.Nussbaum, "Semmei-reki" at p. 840; Bramsen, William. (1880). Japanese chronological tables, p. 25. ==History== The Semmyō-reki or Semmei- reki system corrected errors in earlier calendars which were developed in China.Needham, Joseph. (1959). Science and civilisation in China, Mathematics and the sciences of the heavens and the earth, Vol. 3, p. 391 note d. It was the work of Shibukawa Shunkai and Shikokawa Kōkyō.Nussbaum, "Shibokawa Shunkai" at pp. 850-851. The earliest record of this calendar is in the 8th month of the 3rd year of Jōgan (861) during the reign of the Emperor Seiwa.Japan, Monbushō. (1876). An outline history of Japanese education: prepared for the Philadelphia International Exhibition, 1876, p. 160. ==Related pages== * Japanese calendar * Sexagenary cycle * Genka calendar * Gihō calendar * Taien calendar * Goki calendar ==References== ==Other websites== * National Diet Library, Japanese Calendar" Category:Calendars
title: Semmyō calendar
